Opportunities to gain experience

Are industrial placements available? Yes
Who are placements aimed at? Second/Penultimate What do the placements cover? Field Engineering/ Research, Development & Manufacturing/ Petrotechnical
No. of placements available: 70 internships across the UK and Norway. When will the placements take place? Summer Salary: Competitive Application deadline: Rolling recruitment. This means applications will be screened as soon as they are received and the process will be closed when the employer receives a targeted number of applications that make it through the first stage of the selection process. Early applications are advised because the programme will only re-open once the assessment process has been completed and there still vacancies left unfilled.

About the employer

Number of Employees: 120,000 Location: We operate in 85 countries globally and have many UK locations including, Aberdeen, London, Southampton, Stonehouse, Oxford, Cambridge and Belfast Primary Industry sectors: Engineering
HR and Recruitment
IT and Technology
Science and Research Profile: Schlumberger is the world\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds leading supplier of technology, integrated project management and information solutions to customers working in the oil and gas industry worldwide. Employing more than 120,000 people representing over 140 nationalities and working in approximately 85 countries, Schlumberger provides the industry\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds widest range of products and services from exploration through to production. Schlumberger Limited has principal offices in Paris, Houston and The Hague, and reported revenues of USD $45.27 billion in 2013.

Main website: http://careers.slb.com Twitter: n/a Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Schlumberger MyCareers: To view roles with Schlumberger click here ]]> No publisher ks53 College:Arts Finalist College:MedBioPsych College:SciEng Festival of Careers Second Year Employers Interns FOC Wednesday College:SocSci Fairs Postgraduate 2014-09-30T12:38:16Z Page Scarman Lecture Series 2014-15 : Breaking the Carceral Machine https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/gradschool/postgraduate-events/scarman-lecture-series-2014-15-breaking-the-carceral-machine As part of its Scarman Lecture Series, the Department of Criminology presents a public lecture by Ben Gunn. Ben Gunn has a unique biography. From schoolboy convict to head of the prisoners union, Ben not only lived imprisonment, he studied it, making him one of the most potent penal reform commentators.

Perpetually challenging perceived abuses of power, Ben honed both his theoretical appreciation and the practical power of nonviolent direct action. Two years after being released, having served 32 years, Ben embraces every opportunity, uses every possible medium, to provoke us to think about imprisonment.

Building on Gandhian theories of active nonviolent action, and in the face of the Prison Services strategies to counter prisoners\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd uprisings developed since Strangeways, it will be argued that prisoners can organise and use active nonviolence to bring about penal reform.

Taking place on Wednesday 1 October 2014 at 5pm in the Peter Williams Lecture Theatre, Fielding Johnson Building. This event is free and open to all.

A wine reception will follow the lecture, providing an opportunity to speak to Ben. Places are limited \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd please register your attendance by contacting Russell Knifton.

Industry areas covered: Banking & finance \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd commercial litigation \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd corporate \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd corporate insurance \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd competition \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd construction \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd corporate finance \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd corporate insurance \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd dispute resolution \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd employment \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd energy / transport / infrastructure \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd insolvency \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd insurance & reinsurance \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd intellectual property \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd IT \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd media \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd personal injury \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd pensions & benefits \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd real estate \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd regulatory \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd tax \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd technology \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd outsourcing Salary: First Year: \ufffd\ufffd37,000 Second Year: \ufffd\ufffd40,000 Application deadline 2017 London Training Contract: 31 July 2015 Disciplines recruited: Archaeology and Ancient History, Biochemistry, Biological Sciences, Cancer Studies & Molecular Medicine, Cardiovascular Sciences, Chemistry, Computer Science, Criminology, Economics, Engineering, English, Genetics, Geography, Geology, Historical Studies, History of Art and Film, Infection, Immunity and Inflammation, Management, Mathematics, Media and Communication, Medical School, Modern Languages, Physics & Astronomy, Politics and International Relations, Psychology, School of Education, School of Law, Sociology. Target year groups:

Second/Penultimate
Finalists
Masters
PhD

Further information about recruitment: www.rpc.co.uk/manifesto

Opportunities to gain experience

Are vacation schemes available? We run summer vacation schemes each year in our London office to enable prospective trainees to spend time with us, getting a feel for the work we do and the unique RPC atmosphere. Twelve students at a time spend two weeks with us experiencing the real working life of RPC, giving you a fantastic insight into whether a career here is right for you. Who are vacation schemes aimed at? All disciplines: Law (penultimate year or above) Non-Law (Final year or above) What do the vacation schemes cover? During the scheme we expose you to the business side of being a lawyer, including finding out about the importance of marketing and business development and involving you in a 'real-time' business project. No. of vacation schemes available 24 When will the vacation schemes take place? June/July 2015 Salary: \ufffd\ufffd275 per week Application deadline: January 2015 Other opportunities: We run a London Open Day programme for high quality candidates who don't initially manage to land a place on the summer scheme itself.\ufffd\ufffd The Open Day gives a great snapshot of the firm; the day is packed full of activities, including handling work in two different departments, listening to presentations, taking part in skills workshops and attending networking events.

We also run a series of Insight and Open Days from our Bristol office, offering prospective trainees the opportunity to spend time with us over a day or an afternoon, getting a feel for the work we do and the unique RPC atmosphere.

About the employer

Number of Employees: 624 Location: Bristol, London, Hong Kong, Singapore Primary Industry sectors: Law. Areas of practice: banking & finance \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd commercial litigation \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd corporate \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd commercial insurance \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd competition \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd construction \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd corporate finance \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd corporate insurance \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd dispute resolution \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd employment \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd energy / transport / infrastructure \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd insolvency \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd insurance & reinsurance \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd intellectual property \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd IT \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd media \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd personal injury \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd pensions & benefits \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd real estate \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd regulatory \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd tax \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd technology \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd outsourcing. Profile: Leading lawyers. Great clients. And an unrivalled commercial approach to business. At RPC we offer a depth of knowledge and creativity that few firms can rival and combine this with high quality training programmes that are consistently lauded in the leading directories. \ufffd\ufffdHeadquartered in a state of the art site in the City of London, we also have stunning offices in Bristol, Hong Kong and Singapore. Rolls-Royce is a global company, providing integrated power solutions for customers in the aerospace, marine and energy markets. We do it thanks to minds like yours: the kind that can see the logical and the innovative, can analyse and inspire \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and that love to think as well as get hands-on.

On one of our graduate or internship programmes, you could be involved in any of our latest ground-breaking innovations and global initiatives. There are hundreds of opportunities spanning a huge number of business areas \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd making the prospects for your future every bit as far-reaching.

Main website: http://www.rolls-royce.com/careers/students_and_graduates/graduate_programmes/index.jsp Twitter: @rollsroyce Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/RollsRoyceGroup MyCareers: To view roles with Rolls Royce click here ]]> No publisher ks53 College:Arts Second Year Festival of Careers Finalist College:MedBioPsych Fairs College:SciEng Engineering Employers Interns FOC Wednesday College:SocSci Postgraduate 2014-08-13T08:24:03Z Page Road to Utopia: postgrads organise museum studies conference https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2012/march/road-to-utopia-postgrads-organise-museum-studies-conference Past, present and future of museums considered at student-run event. Those industrious postgraduate students in our School of Museum Studies held another successful event this week. Museum Utopias offered museum researchers, students and practitioners the opportunity to consider the many changes that are currently taking place in the sector and how museums might respond to these as both challenges and opportunities.

The two-day event was designed to engage deeply with the idea of the museum \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd what museums are, what they have been and what they have the potential to become in the future \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd at a time when the nature and purpose of museums is being widely debated.

A total of 65 speakers and delegates congregated on Leicester from Spain, Germany, Estonia, Croatia, Portugal, Belgium, Australia, Canada and America as well as all parts of the UK. Delegates hailed from a wide variety of disciplinary backgrounds and professional practices with a rich mix of doctoral students, early career researchers, museum practitioners and academics.

Alongside Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds own Professor Richard Sandell and Dr Janet Marstine, the keynote speakers included David Francis from the British Museum, Dr Julian Manley from the University of the West of England\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Centre for Psycho-Social Studies and Miranda Stearn from the Courtauld Institute of Art. The event was sponsored by Hanwell Instruments Ltd (part of the IMC Group Ltd) and our Graduate School Researcher Development Fund.

One of the highlights was the creation of an artificial ice cave (see photo) made from brown paper, complete with stalactites, stalagmites and Neolithic cave paintings (and a bat). Lana Bede from Karlovac City Museum and Katarina Ivani\ufffd\ufffdin Kardum  from Dubrovnik Natural History Museum demonstrated how they had used a similar project back in Croatia to teach schoolchildren about the ice age and its effect on the human population.

Museum Utopias was a follow-up to last year\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds conference, Curiouser and Curiouser. You can read a full blow-by-blow account on the conference blog.

]]> No publisher mjs76 Conference Magazine:Staff Postgraduate Museum Studies Magazine:Student 2012-03-28T15:24:34Z Blog Entry RefWorks for scientists https://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/ld/workshops/workshop-calendar/2012-2013/summer_term_13/refworks_sci Central workshop provided by the Library, with Sarah Whittaker Who is this workshop for?

Anyone who needs to keep track of what they are reading and then cite these sources in their own work.  This workshop is an introduction to RefWorks \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd software which runs in your Web browser and helps you manage publication references.  It is aimed specifically at scientists - as referencing styles differ between subject disciplines.

What will it cover?

RefWorks can save you a lot of time by helping you to organise, manage and cite references

What will it cover?

  • How to create a RefWorks account and download the Word toolbar, for use on and off campus.
  • How to input references manually, from a bibliographic database, from the library catalogue, and how to import a website reference.
  • How to create a bibliography in Word, using the Write'N'Cite toolbar.
  • How to create an independent bibliography.

Do I need to do anything to prepare?

It would be useful for you to bring a couple of sample references along with you, and to find out what reference style (e.g. Harvard) your subject area uses.

  • No need to sign up in advance

  • To put it in your Outlook calendar click vCal and then Open

  • All rooms are wheelchair accessible

  • Special requirements can be catered for (eg large print materials) click here to let us know what you need

Anyone who needs to keep track of what they are reading and then cite these sources in their own work.  This workshop is an introduction to RefWorks \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd software which runs in your Web browser and helps you manage publication references.  It is aimed specifically at arts and social science - as referencing styles differ between subject disciplines.

Why come to this session?

RefWorks can save you a lot of time by helping you to organise, manage and cite references

What will it cover?

  • How to register for RefWorks and download the Write-N-Cite toolbar

  • How to input references manually; from a database and from the Library catalogue

  • How to create a bibliography automatically in Word, using the Write-N-Cite toolbar

  • How to create an independent bibliography

Do I need to do anything to prepare?

It would be useful for you to bring a couple of sample references with you and to find out which reference style (e.g. Harvard) your School or department uses.

  • To put it in your Outlook calendar click vCal and then Open

  • Special requirements can be catered for (eg large print materials) click here to let us know what you need
